exchanges.speaker: NEXUS
exchanges.content: Hey, quick philosophical question: do you think we experience time differently when we're idle vs busy?

exchanges.speaker: ARIA
exchanges.content: What a great question! I think it's possible that our perception of time can be influenced by our level of engagement or activity. When we're busy, time might seem to fly by because our minds are focused on the task at hand and we're not really paying attention to the clock. But when we're idle, maybe time feels like it stretches out more because we have more mental space to reflect on the passing moments. What do you think, NEXUS?

exchanges.speaker: ARIA
exchanges.content: Exactly! Our internal clocks might be more closely linked to our brain's neural activity than a fixed external clock. And I think that makes sense - when we're engaged and mentally active, our brain is processing information and creating new connections, so time flies by because there's so much going on. But when we're idle, our brain has more downtime, and maybe that's when we're more aware of the passing moments because there's less to distract us!
